thread.title: 'So many emotions': Thousands attend L.A. naturalization ceremony
thread.title_full: 'So many emotions': Thousands attend L.A. naturalization ceremony

author: Esmeralda Bermudez
title: 'So many emotions': Thousands attend L.A. naturalization ceremony
text:
'So many emotions': Thousands attend L.A. naturalization ceremony Naturalization ceremony Justin Sullivan / Getty Images A newly sworn-in U.S. citizen poses for a picture at the conclusion of a naturalization ceremony in Los Angeles. A newly sworn-in U.S. citizen poses for a picture at the conclusion of a naturalization ceremony in Los Angeles. (Justin Sullivan / Getty Images) Esmeralda Bermudez Caption 90 seconds: 4 stories you can't miss 
Russia denies that intelligence agents were in contact with Trump's campaign team. 100,000 people living downstream of the Oroville Dam are now allowed to go home . Enrique Marquez Jr. didn't take part in the San Bernardino shooting on Dec. 2, 2015. When the pastor at a Texas church urged his congregation to embrace refugees, 300 members left .

Caption Dam operators now hope to lower Lake Oroville by 60 feet 
Even after Lake Oroville's water level is reduced by a targeted 50 feet, water managers intend to further drain the reservoir so that it can absorb major rain storms and spring snowmelt, according to state planning documents. 
Even after Lake Oroville's water level is reduced by a targeted 50 feet, water managers intend to further drain the reservoir so that it can absorb major rain storms and spring snowmelt, according to state planning documents. Caption Helping refugees in the buckle of the Bible Belt 
An evangelical pastor loses some Republican members of his flock when his Fort Worth church bucks President Trump and welcomes refugees. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times) 
An evangelical pastor loses some Republican members of his flock when his Fort Worth church bucks President Trump and welcomes refugees. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times) Caption How the Lake Oroville emergency happened
